Everyone who comes to learn should feel welcome here. We are committed to providing a professional, friendly and safe environment for all participants regardless of gender, sexual orientation, disability, race, ethnicity, religion, national origin or other protected class.
Please see a full code of conduct here:

Meeting you where you are



I’ll assume you

have limited or no R knowlege
have worked in Microsoft/Google Spreadsheets
have written a report on something
want to learn!




I’ll teach you

basics of a using R
how to get unstuck
a framework of tools you can reuse!

title: Getting Started with R in Environmental Science
text:
Workshop approach
We will use real bioassessment data to demonstrate some general data approaches to using open and reproducible workflows in R to summarizing and plotting data!.


 Conventions








🧰
Add this to your toolbox.


📣
Important announcement typically learned via trial and error…let us save you the pain



Detour warning. There’s a lot more to talk about here but, but there’s not time today.

title: Getting Started with R in Environmental Science
text:
Asking Questions




You are always welcome to raise your hand! 🙋






Also feel free to ask in our shared doc!

title: Getting Started with R in Environmental Science
text:
Getting help (R Functions)
Functions are the 🍞 and 🧈 of R programming!


If you want to access any function’s help page:
# Method 1
help(function_name_here)

# Method 2
?function_name_here

# Method 3
# Highlight the function and press F1 🤯

Wrangling to Workflow


hopefully we now have an idea how to go from just wrangling…
to workflows using re-useable tools!

title: Tying it Together! 🪢
text:
Quarto

is a (relatively) new, open-source, scientific, and technical publishing system
aims to make the process of creating and collaborating dramatically better


Subsequent slides are adapted from the excellent Quarto Dashboard workshop by Mine Çetinkaya-Rundel from posit::conf(2024)

title: Tying it Together! 🪢
text:
Quarto ➝ many outputs
With Quarto you can weave together narrative text and code to produce elegantly formatted output as documents, web pages, blog posts, books, and more…

title: Tying it Together! 🪢
text:
Installing Quarto
Best Approach:

Go to the Quarto website and download!

title: Tying it Together! 🪢
text:

Tip


Run the following in your Terminal to find your Quarto version:


Terminal

quarto --version

title: Tying it Together! 🪢
text:
Documents

Lots of options .pdf, .html, .docx
Easiest to start with .html!
We can embed our code and figures with the text!
Click “Render” = AutoMagically make a report!

title: Tying it Together! 🪢
text:
Step 2: Add a card



dashboard-r.qmd

---
title: "My first Quarto dashboard"
format: dashboard
---

```{r}
library(ggplot2)
```

```{r}
ggplot(mpg, aes(x = cty, y = hwy)) +
  geom_point()
```

title: Tying it Together! 🪢
text:
Step 4: Add titles to cards



dashboard-r.qmd

---
title: "My first Quarto dashboard"
format: dashboard
---

```{r}
library(ggplot2)
```

```{r}
#| title: Highway vs. city mileage
ggplot(mpg, aes(x = cty, y = hwy)) +
  geom_point()
```

```{r}
#| title: Drive types
ggplot(mpg, aes(x = drv)) +
  geom_bar()
```

title: Tying it Together! 🪢
text: Steps 1 - 4

title: Learning R: Workflow vs Wrangling
text:
Overview
You likely already wrangle, analyze, and report environmental data of all types. Perhaps you use R sometimes, or maybe never before. But certainly you likely do similar tasks over and over, maybe using the same tools (e.g., Excel), or maybe a number of different tools. Are your tools re-usable? Can you reproduce your work efficiently and easily, building on the previous experience?
No matter the answer to these questions, this workshop will try to get through some of the basic principles of data wrangling and summarizing in R, how to re-use these tools, and how to build a reproducible workflow you can use to tackle whatever data challenge gets thrown your way.
We will walk through how to get data into R, how to summarize, join, and plot our data, as well as how to make some basic maps. Finally, we will touch on how to put this into a single report that you can re-use or revise as you see fit.
This course is for you if you:

do data analysis in Excel
do anything with spreadsheets and environmental data
use a computer regularly
generate summaries or reports that use environmental data
have used R before
have never used R before

title: Learning R: Workflow vs Wrangling
text:
Instructor
Ryan Peek is Senior Environmental Scientist (Specialist) at California Department of Fish and Wildlife and reasearcher with UC Davis. Ryan prefers being outside in flowing water over most any other environment, and has worked in a wide range of environments and subject areas including biodiversity, climate change, drought, environmental monitoring, genomics, hydrology, aquatic ecology, food webs, conservation biology, and especially anything having to do with frogs.

title: Learning R: Workflow vs Wrangling
text:
Website
Website and slides, all built in Quarto with RStudio! Styles, Themes, and Layouts adapted/reused from the excellent posit::conf(2024) repo, specifically the Quarto Dashboard Workshop. Some fantastic resources exist that have been invaluable for learning how to put these types of workshops together, thanks to the open, available, and re-useable approach folks have taken. For Quarto Live / WASM, the excellent R Primers site by Andrew Heiss was invaluable.

title: Learning R: Workflow vs Wrangling
text:
Content
Content is largely built and adapted from the CABW 2018 R Training, and influenced by the excellent Carpentries workshops and community, Openscapes resources (including a Water Boards specific program), and the Davis R Users Group and R4WRDS course.
Ultimately, everything is and should be open to all for use, reuse, and learning.
